Calculating a \(V_{max}\) and \(K_{m}\) for an Enzyme

How tightly does my protein bind?

Author

Brady Johnston

Published

April 7, 2022

Playing around with modelling dose-response curves in R, to calculate a \(K_{d}\) for an interaction between a protein and it’s potential binding target. From this we can compare the rates of two enzymes, and see if our mutation had any effect. Ther results of which can be seen below in Table 1.1

library(biochemr)
mod <- Puromycin %>% 
  bio_enzyme_rate(conc, rate, group = state)

purrr::map(mod$model, broom::glance)
[[1]]
# A tibble: 1 x 4
    AIC   BIC logLik    df.residual
  <dbl> <dbl> <logLik>        <int>
1  95.3  96.7 -44.63548          10

[[2]]
# A tibble: 1 x 4
    AIC   BIC logLik   df.residual
  <dbl> <dbl> <logLik>       <int>
1  85.2  86.4 -39.5805           9
mod %>% 
  bio_plot(colour = state, facet = FALSE) + 
  ggplot2::coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, NA))
mod %>% 
  bio_coefs() %>% 
  knitr::kable()
Table 1: The resulting coefficients from the model.
state term estimate std.error statistic p.value
treated Vmax 212.6838544 7.1606488 29.701757 0.0000000
treated Km 0.0641215 0.0087112 7.360806 0.0000242
untreated Vmax 160.2802158 6.8060674 23.549607 0.0000000
untreated Km 0.0477084 0.0084203 5.665846 0.0003073

Is there actually a difference between the two sates? We can see their fits inside of Figure 1 but we are unsure if it will actually be significant. We can compare the two models:

comp <- purrr::reduce(mod$model, anova) %>% 
  tibble::as_tibble() %>% 
  dplyr::mutate(model = as.character(mod$state))

1st model
 fct:      .model
2nd model
 fct:      .model
comp
# A tibble: 2 x 6
  ModelDf   RSS    Df `F value` `p value` model    
    <int> <dbl> <int>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    
1      10 1195.    NA     NA      NA      treated  
2       9  860.     1      3.52    0.0935 untreated

By the looks of things, we probably couldn’t say that there was actually a real difference between the two states, with a p-value of only 0.094 .

1 What about with a different data set?

Code
mod <- DNase %>% 
  tibble::as_tibble() %>% 
  bio_binding(conc, density, Run)

 
bio_plot(mod,colour = Run) + 
  ggplot2::theme_classic()

Code
mod %>% 
  bio_coefs() %>% 
  knitr::kable()

Footnotes

  1. This isn’t actually the best way to go about it. There are far too many details, which are more useful if you are doing more advance modelling, but we are just after an estimate of the \(K_{m}\) and the \(V_{max}\) from our data.↩︎
